body:
yes, `license.txt` should be `LICENSE.md`
note that scikit-learn uses "the scikit-learn developers" as author for their BSD 3-clause license
I would guess that they must have put some thought into that
Therefore I would be on board with "the Kymatio developers" in this case
I think that's fine. To make sure it's autodetected by GitHub, it might be good to just follow link #2 above and create a new one instead of renaming (after making sure it is indeed, 3-BSD).

Yes, I think that the choice of 3-BSD was a decision by @eugenium and @szagoruyko 
Probably informed by scikit-learn which is also 3-BSD
I usually do MIT which is very close to 3-BSD, except for the 3rd clause which is all fine by me
I don't see a compelling reason to shift to MIT, and I think we'd be shooting ourselves in the foot if we were to use a less permissive license like GNU
I will open a PR

> Yes, I think that the choice of 3-BSD was a decision by @eugenium and @szagoruyko
> Probably informed by scikit-learn which is also 3-BSD
> I usually do MIT which is very close to 3-BSD, except for the 3rd clause which is all fine by me
> I don't see a compelling reason to shift to MIT, and I think we'd be shooting ourselves in the foot if we were to use a less permissive license like GNU

Ok sounds good.
> I will open a PR

Please do!

I can update the text of the license right now, but getting GitHub's license detection mechanism to recognize our `LICENSE` as `BSD-3-Clause` might be harder than expected.
See this open issue on the Go language for example:
https://github.com/golang/dep/issues/1431

Believe it or not, this looks more and more like a `wontfix`
https://github.com/golang/dep/issues/1431#issuecomment-441728253

Huh. Did you try

https://help.github.com/articles/adding-a-license-to-a-repository/

on a branch to see what it does?

Yes. It id not possible to set a license on a branch or fork via the GitHub API.
And in kymatio/kymatio -> insights -> community, the license appears in green, which AFAICT is irreversible.

Bleuh...

It seems like it lets me do it on the main repo. Maybe we could try this and rollback the commit if it doesn't work?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3976052/49055580-18ff4000-f1c6-11e8-8e3b-aec91d107ef9.png)
closed by the capable hands of @janden
